Description: Dava Pharmaceuticals Inc. agreed to pay the United States $11 million to settle allegations that it violated the False Claims Act by misreporting drug prices in order to reduce its Medicaid Drug Rebate obligations.

Primary Offense: off-label or unapproved promotion of medical products
Description: Pharmaceutical company Endo Health Solutions Inc. and its subsidiary Endo Pharmaceuticals Inc. agreed to pay $192.7 million to resolve criminal and civil liability arising from Endo's marketing of the prescription drug Lidoderm for uses not approved as safe and effective by the Food and Drug Administration. The resolution included a deferred prosecution agreement and forfeiture totaling $20.8 million and civil false claims settlements with the federal government and the states and the District of Columbia totaling $171.9 million.
Agency: Food and Drug Administration referral to the Justice Department

Company: Endo Pharmaceuticals Inc. and Vintage Pharmaceuticals, LLC d/b/a Qualitest Pharmaceuticals
Primary Offense: drug or medical equipment safety violation
Description: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York and the Office of Inspector General for the Department of Health and Human Services announced a $39 million settlement against Vintage Pharmaceuticals, LLC d/b/a Qualitest Pharmaceuticals and  Vintage's corporate parent Endo Pharmaceuticals, Inc. in a civil fraud lawsuit.
Agency: U.S. Attorney-Southern District of New York

Primary Offense: off-label or unapproved promotion of medical products
Description: New Jersey-based Par Pharmaceutical Companies Inc. pleaded guilty in federal court and agreed to pay $45 million to resolve its criminal and civil liability in the company's promotion of its prescription drug Megace ES for uses not approved as safe and effective by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and not covered by federal health care programs.
Agency: Food and Drug Administration referral to the Justice Department

Description: Dava Pharmaceuticals agreed to pay $11 million to settle multistate litigation alleging that it misclassified drugs to evade paying its rebate obligations to Medicaid. The settlement also involved the federal government, which issued its own announcement; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-dava-pharmaceuticals-inc

Primary Offense: off-label or unapproved promotion of medical products
Description: Endo Health Solutions agreed to pay $173 million to settle multistate litigation alleging unlawful marketing practices aimed at promoting the drug Lidoderm for conditions not approved by the Food and Drug Administration. This was part of a larger $192.7 million civil and criminal settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-endo-health-solutions-inc

Qualitest Pharmaceuticals, Inc., a manufacturer of generic pharmaceutical products, and its parent company, Endo Health Solutions, agreed to pay $39 million as part of the settlement of multistate litigation alleging unlawful labeling practices; specifically, selling multivitamin tablets said to contain the American Dental Association (ADA) amount of fluoride when they actually contained less than half that amount. Also involved in the settlement was the federal government, which issued its own announcement; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-endo-pharmaceuticals-inc-and-vintage-pha

Company: Endo Health Solutions Inc. and Endo Pharmaceuticals Inc.
Primary Offense: drug or medical equipment safety violation

Description: Endo International plc and Endo Pharmaceuticals Inc. agreed to pay $2.3 million to resolve multistate litigation alleging anti-competitive, "pay-for-delay" conduct related to Endo's sale of Lidoderm, a pain-relief drug that treats complications from shingles.
The state had accused Endo of entering collusive agreements to delay the introduction of lower-cost substitutes for its Lidoderm medical patch for shingles pain.
Falsification of wholesale drug price reporting. Federal government shared in the settlement. Penalty amount listed here is state portion only.
Info Source: Attorney General Abbott Recovers $36.34 Million for State of Texas, U.S., Targeted News Service, January 4, 2013 (via Nexis).

Description: The Louisiana Attorney General's Office announced that it had obtained a total of $88 million in settlements from 25 pharmaceutical companies to resolve allegations they overcharged the state's Medicaid program.

Three companies agreed to pay a total of $6.032 million to settle litigation relating to the misreporting of wholesale drug prices, thus increased prices for the state's Medicaid program. The announcement did not indicate how much each would pay. Here we assume the total was divided equally among the three.

Primary Offense: off-label or unapproved promotion of medical products
Description: Par Pharmaceutical agreed to pay $22.5 million to a group of states and the federal government to settle allegations that it promoted its prescription drug Megace ES for uses not approved by the Food and Drug Administration. This was part of a larger $45 million civil and criminal settlement announced by the U.S. Justice Department; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-par-pharmaceutical-companies-inc
Par Pharmaceutical Cos., Inc.  agreed to pay $1.7 million in settlement of allegations  it misreported the average wholesale price of its drugs.
Par Pharmaceutical Inc. agreed to pay $4.5 million in settlement of alleged improper reporting of the average wholesale price of its drugs, causing Medicaid to overpay.
Par Pharmaceutical, Inc. agreed to pay $500,000 in settlement of alleged improper reporting of the average wholesale price of its drugs, causing Medicaid to pay inflated amounts.

Par Pharmaceuticals agreed to pay $154 million to five states -- Alaska, Florida, Kentucky, South Carolina and Texas -- to settle litigation alleging that it reported false and inflated prices of medications to state Medicaid programs.
Info Source: Attorney General Bondi's Office Recovers More than $26 Million from Pharmaceutikcal Company in Medicaid Fraud Settlement, States News Service, August 25, 2011 (via Nexis).

Description: The Oklahoma Attorney General reached an out-of-court settlement with Endo Pharmaceuticals totaling $8.75 million for the company's alleged role in the state's opioid crisis.

Primary Offense: off-label or unapproved promotion of medical products
Description: settlement with drug manufacturer in multi-company opioid litigation

Primary Offense: drug or medical equipment safety violation
Description: Endo International announced that it would pay $775 million to resolve virtually all of the outstanding multi-district litigation over alleged harm caused by the vaginal mesh products made by its American Medical Systems Inc. subsidiary: https://investor.endo.com/news-releases/news-release-details/endo-announces-agreements-resolve-virtually-all-known-us-mesh. This came three years after the company announced it would pay $830 million to settle most of the suits that had been outstanding at that time (see separate entry).
Private Litigation Case Title: In Re: American Medical Systems, Inc., Pelvic Repair System Products Liability Litigation

Description: Endo Health Solutions agreed to pay $15.5 million to settle a class action alleging that the company's multi-vitamins did not contain as much fluoride as advertised.
Private Litigation Case Title: Mahoney v. Endo Health Solutions, Inc.

Primary Offense: drug or medical equipment safety violation
Description: Endo International announced that it would pay $830 million to resolve most of the outstanding multi-district litigation over alleged harm caused by the vaginal mesh products made by its American Medical Systems Inc. subsidiary: https://investor.endo.com/news-releases/news-release-details/endo-reaches-agreements-principle-settle-substantial-majority
Private Litigation Case Title: In Re: American Medical Systems, Inc., Pelvic Repair System Products Liability Litigation

Company: Endo Health Solutions Inc. and Endo Pharmaceuticals Inc.
Primary Offense: off-label or unapproved promotion of medical products
Description: Endo agreed to pay $65 million ($55 million for opioid remediation and up to $10 million litigation costs) in settlement of allegations the company violated Florida law by deceptively marketing opioid pain medications by downplaying the associated risks and also failed to monitor and report suspicious orders of opioid pain medication.
